title: How Gregory Bovino became the face of Trump’s immigration crackdown | CNN Politics
excerpt: A year ago, few Americans knew Gregory Bovino’s name. Now the commander – sporting a buzzcut and the Border Patrol’s green uniform – has been spotted in multiple US cities leading patrols, hurling tear gas canisters and verbally sparring with critics.
content:
A year ago, few Americans knew [Gregory Bovino](https://www.cnn.com/2025/10/08/politics/gregory-bovino-border-patrol-chicago-immigration)’s name. Now he’s the face of the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown.

And everything from the Border Patrol commander-at-large’s [tactics in the field](https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2026/01/09/us/dhs-immigration-crackdown-ice-arrests-protests-vis/index.html) to his wardrobe choices have become lightning rods in a storm with no end in sight.

On the streets of multiple American cities, Bovino – sporting a buzzcut and the Border Patrol’s olive green uniform – has been spotted leading patrols, hurling tear gas canisters and verbally sparring with critics. He often stands out among groups of federal officers as one of the few people not wearing a mask.

On social media, he’s known for sharing photos and cinematic videos that tout Border Patrol agents’ determination to carry out their mission.

And now, his presence at the podium and on screens around the world is becoming more common as he delivers briefings from Minneapolis.

That’s where Bovino stood hours after a Border Patrol officer shot and killed a man in that city Saturday, telling reporters that officers had followed their training when faced with an armed suspect who “wanted to do maximum damage and massacre law enforcement.”

Critics quickly slammed Bovino’s statement and others from Homeland Security officials, arguing that [videos of the shooting](https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/24/us/invs-videos-show-federal-officer-recovered-gun) show no evidence the man was trying to harm anyone.

But Bovino doubled down on his defense of officers Sunday.

“The fact that they’re highly trained prevented any specific shootings of law enforcement, so good job for our law enforcement in taking him down before he was able to do that,” Bovino [told CNN’s “State of the Union.”](https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/25/politics/video/bovino-dana-bash-full-interview-digvid)

Pressed to provide evidence, Bovino said more details would emerge as authorities investigate and argued that the man was trying to impede officers.

“It’s too bad the consequences had to be paid because he injected himself into that crime scene. I can’t say that enough. He made the decision to go there,” Bovino said.

The Border Patrol official’s account drew sharp criticism Sunday morning from Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy.

“Everybody saw that video, and yet there he was telling you and telling the American public that this young man was brandishing a weapon, that he was impeding officers, that he was there to attend a riot, that he was engaged in assault, when everyone can see that that’s not true,” Murphy told CNN. “It should freak the American public out that the Trump administration lies this easily, will lie to your face when you can see the evidence for yourself.”

Bovino is no stranger to criticisms of his approach. For months in interviews, court testimony and social media posts, he’s repeatedly defended federal officers’ actions and vowed not to back down.

In multiple social media posts and interviews, Bovino has repeatedly [used a phrase](https://x.com/CMDROpAtLargeCA/status/2010151928332706081?s=20) to describe his officers’ tactics.

“He calls them ‘turn and burn,’” [CNN contributor Lulu Garcia-Navarro says](https://transcripts.cnn.com/show/ebo/date/2025-10-07/segment/01). “They’re very rapid. They’re very aggressive. Break windows, go in, grab people. And the reason he says that he does these tactics is to not put …agents at risk, not to allow protests to develop.”

Supporters of the administration’s aggressive mass deportation push see Bovino as a hero. But the forceful, unapologetic approach that’s fueled his recent rise to prominence has also drawn fierce criticism from local leaders and protesters in cities his team is targeting.

Officials in several cities have described Bovino as leading a law enforcement agency which [deploys tactics](https://www.cnn.com/2025/10/07/politics/video/gregory-bovino-border-patrol-aggressive-tactics-vrtc) that are frighteningly authoritarian and used by the president as a cudgel against Democrat-led communities and the people — citizens and noncitizens alike — who live in them.

“They want mayhem on the ground,” Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker [told CNN in October](https://transcripts.cnn.com/show/sotu/date/2025-10-05/segment/01), accusing Bovino and other federal officials of deliberately inflaming tensions. “They want to create the war zone, so that they can send in even more troops.”

[Heavy-handed tactics](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/25/us/masks-arrests-ice-tactics-immigration), including immigration sweeps in parking lots and smashing car windows, have fueled alarm, including among some in the Trump administration, while also garnering praise from senior Homeland Security officials.

Asked about the aggressive approach that has spurred growing criticism and protests, Bovino has defended his officers.

“You know, folks are free to criticize. They’re free to armchair quarterback. When they don’t walk a mile in the shoes of law enforcement, then they might want to think a second before full-blown criticism. I’ve heard a lot of that,” [he told CNN in October](https://www.cnn.com/2025/10/07/politics/video/gregory-bovino-border-patrol-aggressive-tactics-vrtc). “Our officers act legally, ethically and morally in all law enforcement actions.”

On Sunday, Murphy said on CNN’s “State of the Union” that the latest shooting in Minneapolis should spur lawmakers to press for reforms within the Department of Homeland Security before approving its budget.

“People being killed simply for exercising their First Amendment rights is going to be a regular feature in this country. That is dystopian. We shouldn’t allow for it, and that should unite Republicans and Democrats in Congress, because it’s increasingly uniting Republicans and Democrats all around the country who are turning against this just unbelievably lawless way that Bovino and his team are operating in our cities,” he said.

Bovino’s [presence in different cities](https://www.cnn.com/2025/11/13/us/charlotte-gregory-bovino-border-patrol) across the country in recent months has become an unofficial barometer of how intense immigration enforcement is expected to get.

These days, Bovino is a frequent sight on the streets of Minneapolis – bringing what he calls the “Mean Green Team” thousands of miles from the sector along the US-Mexico border where he was stationed before.

“The [#MeanGreen](https://x.com/hashtag/MeanGreen?src=hashtag_click) is patrolling Minneapolis through the cold, through the snow, and through it all arresting illegal aliens until the mission is accomplished,” Bovino posted Friday on X. “We’re here and we’re making the city safe.”

Originally from North Carolina, Bovino joined the Border Patrol in 1996. His 30-year career has taken him from Washington to New Orleans as well as foreign postings in Honduras and Africa. In 2020 he was named Chief Patrol Agent of the El Centro Sector of Southern California.

In 2023, Bovino was briefly relieved of command from his position in what House Republicans described as a retaliatory measure after he testified critically about conditions along the border under President Joe Biden’s administration. [The Associated Press reported](https://apnews.com/article/gregory-bovino-immigration-takeaways-282bcb88d370a77e5188ef97931aff6e) other factors were also at play – including his social-media presence and an online profile picture of him posing with an assault rifle.

He began drawing public attention last summer, when he helped orchestrate the arrests of more than 5,000 immigrants in a Los Angeles operation. Since then, Bovino – who’s in his mid-fifties – has led sweeps in Chicago, Charlotte, New Orleans and, now, Minneapolis.

Bovino’s conduct during the Chicago operation drew stern rebukes from a federal judge, who ruled that [his descriptions of events weren’t supported by video evidence](https://www.cnn.com/2025/11/06/us/gregory-bovino-deposition-chicago-immigration).

In one video, cited in a federal court case alleging excessive force against protesters in Chicago, the judge ruled that Bovino “obviously tackles” a protester on camera. But in his deposition, Bovino denied he tackled the man. “I’m imploring (him)…to comply with leaving the area to comply with instructions,” Bovino said, adding, “the use of force was against me.”

Lately, another aspect of Bovino’s image is also drawing attention: the long green trench coach he sometimes wears.

“Greg Bovino dressed up as if he literally went on eBay and purchased SS garb. Greg Bovino, secret police, private army, masked men, people disappearing quite literally, no due process,” California Gov. Gavin Newsom said recently, drawing a comparison to Nazi uniforms.

Bovino says he’s had the jacket for more than 25 years, and got it from the Border Patrol.

“I bought that as a young agent, approximately 1999,” [he told News Nation](https://x.com/CMDROpAtLargeCA/status/2015077205236146510?s=20), noting that he was also photographed wearing it for a ceremony during the Biden administration.

That interview, Bovino wrote on social media, “cleared up any misconceptions and highlighted the double standard phenomenon.”

Whatever happens next, there’s little doubt we’ll be seeing more of Bovino – and his coat – on America’s streets.

Slickly produced videos and other social media posts from Bovino’s accounts have also drawn criticism. He says the posts are aimed at increasing transparency.

“This is not agenda-driven. Our social media is designed to give the public … a real-time snapshot of what is really happening,” [Bovino told CNN in October](https://www.cnn.com/2025/10/08/politics/gregory-bovino-border-patrol-chicago-immigration).

Among his recent posts, [Bovino shared a video clip](https://x.com/CMDROpAtLargeCA/status/2014370486151508278?s=20) of his response during a press briefing to a reporter who asked when the surge of federal law enforcement into Minneapolis will end.

“Is there a certain number of people you want to apprehend before you decide to ease the surge?” the reporter asked.

“There is a number,” Bovino said, “and it’s called all of them.”

CNN’s Priscilla Alvarez, Michael Williams, Dianne Gallagher and Zoe Sottile contributed to this report.
author: Catherine E. Shoichet

title: Power outages skyrocket in the South from destructive ice as heavy snow piles up in Northeast | CNN
excerpt: A monstrous storm with ice and heavy snow is reaching its peak and combining with brutal cold to raise the danger for millions. Here’s the latest.
content:
• **Crippling blow: **A massive winter storm’s damaging ice has** **knocked out power to [1 million customers](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmku24pvl00003b6uytcztf0y) across the mid-Atlantic and South. The outages could [last for days](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktyno3x00053b6s8ux2ayg9) in hard-hit Nashville and beyond.

• **Schools, travel shut down:** Over 16,000 flights, [an extraordinary amount,](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktpobsq00003b6w9yhz6cu3)have been canceled during the storm [as airports shut down](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktvd19000053b6tp29f4rjo). Schools [in major cities](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktus7yp000i3b6wmxf1s0kl) across the US have canceled or moved classes to remote learning for Monday.

• **Big Northeast snow:** Heavy snow [was falling](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktkl32m00003b6vgokhhe0e) in the Northeast’s highly populous Interstate-95 corridor with some cities, [including Boston](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktwv6no00003b6sqgovxygn), expecting their most snow in years.

• **Deadly, record cold:** At least [seven](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmku3a10000003b6xfv8casfg) [people](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-24-26-climate?post-id=cmkt8f88300053b6sv4r689rk) [have](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-24-26-climate?post-id=cmksw1m8500053b71v2y58t79) [died](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktyl0j900003b6sr6w3d9fd) in the coldest temperatures of winter. The cold will linger into the week, raising fears for those without shelter or power for days.

This loop shows the storm’s precipitation potpourri as it moved across the country over the weekend, with snow, freezing rain, sleet and rain enveloping much of the US.

A tornado is currently active in Florida’s Panhandle as the same storm bringing ice and snow to millions is generating some severe thunderstorms in the Southeast.

Damaging winds are the main threat with any of the storms this afternoon, but more tornadoes are possible.

“At 130 PM CST, a confirmed tornado was located near De Funiak Springs, moving east at 45 mph,” the National Weather Service in Tallahassee, Florida, warned. “TAKE COVER NOW!”

The mayor of Austin, Texas, announced the first death in the area from the winter storm.

The death was related to exposure to the storm, Mayor Kirk Watson said at a [news conference](https://x.com/KirkPWatson/status/2015483553463636080?s=20) Sunday.

Watson urged residents to continue to stay inside and use local resources if they need help.

“I can’t stress enough the importance of staying indoors during this severe weather, even though we’ve made it through the night. … We are still in store for very, very cold weather,” he warned.

At least seven people have died during the coldest temperatures of winter.

Heavy snow has begun to transition to a wintry mix in New York City, where 7.2 inches had fallen as of 1 p.m. in Central Park.

Snowfall amounts ranged from between 6 to just over 9 inches in the metropolitan area, with the highest amounts in northern New Jersey.

The forecast calls for a mix of snow and sleet to fall north and west of the city through the afternoon, while the city may see a period of heavy sleet into the early evening.

Sleet occurs when snow falls through a warm layer of air in the lower atmosphere, melts and then refreezes into ice pellets before reaching the ground.

New York City was expected to see between 10 to 14 inches of snow, but because of the wintry mix, snowfall amounts may be held to the lower end of that range in the city itself.

The Memphis Grizzlies were supposed to host the Denver Nuggets at the FedExForum on Sunday afternoon, but the game will be postponed due to the winter storm.

The team announced the change around 12:30 p.m. CT – just 30 minutes before doors were scheduled to open for the 2:30 p.m. tipoff. The Memphis area is under a winter storm warning until 6 p.m., [according to the National Weather Service](https://www.weather.gov/meg/). Dangerously cold conditions are expected this evening.

The game will be rescheduled, but a new date has not yet been announced. Tickets for Sunday’s contest will be valid for the makeup game,[the Grizzles posted on their X account](https://x.com/memgrizz/status/2015492631086743997).

The team is currently scheduled to play the Rockets on Monday in Houston.

The US has reached 1 million customers without power from the winter storm, according to tracking website [PowerOutage.us](http://poweroutage.us/).

Southern states where ice has accumulated and caused tree limbs to fall on power lines have the most outages, but the outage footprint is expanding into the mid-Atlantic.

Tennessee has over 330,000 customers without power, Mississippi has over 160,000, Louisiana has over 135,000 and Texas has over 90,000.

More than 17,000 flights have been canceled in the US since Saturday as a massive winter storm swept eastward across the country, starting at the lower Rockies and heading to the East Coast.

With more than [10,800 flight cancellations](https://www.flightaware.com/live/cancelled/today) as of 2:20 p.m. ET per FlightAware, Sunday is the worst day for air travel in half a decade. It trails just behind March 30, 2020, which saw 12,143 cancellations during the early days of the Covid pandemic shutdowns, according to aviation analytics company Cirium.

More than [4,100 flights were canceled](https://www.flightaware.com/live/cancelled/yesterday) Saturday as the storm ramped up, and another [2,200 have already been canceled](https://www.flightaware.com/live/cancelled/tomorrow) on Monday, a number which is expected to continue rising.

New York’s LaGuardia Airport is closed, according to multiple alerts from the Federal Aviation Administration.

An FAA Notice to Airmen issued at 1:05 p.m. EST says the airport will remain closed until 8 p.m. EST.

A publicly available FAA operations plan says LaGuardia is closed “as the airport authority treats runways.”

The latest aviation weather report from LaGuardia shows low visibility and heavy blowing snow.

As of 2 p.m. EST, FlightAware shows that 91% of all flights out of LaGuardia have been canceled, along with 97% of arriving flights.

Lehigh Valley International Airport in Pennsylvania is closed because of the weather, the airport posted to X.

It’s one of [several US airports to close](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktvd19000053b6tp29f4rjo) since Saturday’s [record-high number of flight cancellations](https://www.cnn.com/weather/live-news/winter-storm-forecast-snow-ice-01-25-26-climate?post-id=cmktpobsq00003b6w9yhz6cu3).

The Lehigh Valley airport canceled 14 flights in the past 24 hours, [FlightAware data](https://www.flightaware.com/live/airport/KABE) shows.

Power poles snapped as ice accumulates on power lines

00:37

• Source:

[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/)

Power poles snapped as ice accumulates on power lines

00:37

New footage from storm chaser Brandon Clement shows just how devastating this winter storm’s ice has been for power infrastructure in Mississippi.

Power pole after power pole is snapped at the base by the weight of the ice, which is so thick on the lines still standing, it makes them look like ghastly, translucent ropes, drooping on their own in midair.

Snow is piling up in Ohio as the massive storm continues to generate significant totals on its northern side.

A huge stripe of 6 to 10 inches of snow has already fallen from Cincinnati through Columbus to near Youngstown, along the border with Pennsylvania. A few locations around the Dayton and Springfield areas in the western portion of the state have picked up a foot of snow.

The snow is wreaking havoc on area roadways. Columbus Mayor Andrew Ginther [urged residents](https://x.com/ColumbusGov/status/2015471441928483038?s=20) to avoid all travel while the city is under a Level 3 Snow Emergency.

“It is really, really dangerous out there,” Ginther said in a video posted to social media on Sunday. “You should be at home unless there is an absolute emergency.”

The Ohio State University’s Columbus campus canceled in-person classes for Monday and Tuesday due to the heavy snow. “We anticipate classes and normal campus operations resuming on Wednesday, January 28, unless weather conditions dictate otherwise,” the university [said in a news alert](https://news.osu.edu/ohio-state-news-alert-columbus-campus-weather-update/).

Richard Wayner had to get his running miles in Sunday despite the heavy snowfall and bitter cold blanketing New York City.

Wayner was on his seventh mile near Central Park as snow was rapidly coming down, with frozen eyelashes and eyebrows covered in frost. “I feel like when it snows, everything kind of slows down,” he told CNN. “Everything is calm, the city gets quiet — it’s like you’re in the forest now.”

For UPS worker Tyrell Lewis, the feeling was one of relief as he headed back home after working outdoors ahead of the storm. “It’s crazy out here. I’m sick of it,” Lewis said, adding he plans on staying home tomorrow in the aftermath of the storm.

A handful of runners, dog walkers and curious New Yorkers were the only dark specks in the sea of white snow covering Central Park.

For Mick Bonde, going outside was more of an obligation: He was walking his dog.

“This is what I was expecting,” Bonde said of the snow. “I went to bed last night and I didn’t see a whole lot, so I’m glad to see that there’s something accumulating and sticking to the ground.”

Watch: A drive through West Orange, New Jersey, as snow blankets the area

00:33

• Source:

[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/)

Watch: A drive through West Orange, New ...

00:33

Video captured by photojournalist Rod Griola shows snow-covered roads and neighborhoods in West Orange, New Jersey, as the storm moves through the area.

Damage from ice is widespread in the college town of Oxford, Mississippi, with trees and power lines buckling from the storm.

Oxford is in Lafayette County, where about 75% of its more than 26,000 electric customers have no power as of 1:15 p.m. ET, making it the worst hit county in the state, according to [PowerOutage.us](https://poweroutage.us/area/state/mississippi).

“It’s a very dangerous situation,” said [North East Mississippi Electric Power Association](https://x.com/NorthEastPower/status/2015416935417016614) CEO & General Manager Keith Hayward. “Most of our system is on the ground or has trees or damage already.”

Oxford Utilities said “damage is widespread in Oxford and on our neighboring utility systems” in a post on X.

[Oxford Police warned](https://x.com/OxfordPolice/status/2015448061707800609) there were active power lines down across Highway 7 and that several people had driven over those live lines. “Please stay home unless it’s an absolute emergency,” [police said](https://x.com/OxfordPolice/status/2015441010482942063).

The University of Mississippi has already canceled classes for Tuesday given the “[significant disruption](https://x.com/OleMiss/status/2015473103917527506)” to the community due to power outages and unsafe roads.

Watch: Water main break shuts down stretch of Highway 51 south of Charlotte

00:26

• Source:

[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/)

Watch: Water main break shuts down stretch of ...

00:26

A water main break in Pineville, North Carolina, just south of Charlotte, in freezing temperatures shut down portion of highway after it turned everything to ice, according to CNN affiliate WSOC.

The Pineville Police Department in North Carolina says a section of Highway 51, was shut down Sunday morning after the pipe broke. It has since reopened, WSOC reported.

Temperatures dropped to around 18 degrees overnight in the Charlotte area, which is about 15 degrees colder than a normal late January night.

The city is still only hovering around 20 degrees early Sunday afternoon.

Firefighters battle blaze among freezing temperatures

Firefighters battle house fire amid freezing temperatures and surrounded by snow in Oklahoma City.

00:51

• Source:

[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/)

Firefighters battle blaze among freezing ...

00:51

A house in southeast Oklahoma City was “almost totally engulfed” by flames and smoke and surrounded by snow from the storm on Sunday, according to CNN affiliate KOCO News 5.

The home’s two occupants had reported a fire in their garage and were able to escape, according to Oklahoma City fire department spokesperson Scott Douglas. No injuries were reported, but the fire caused “significant damage” to the garage and attic, as well as smoke damage throughout the home, Douglas said.

The fire department is currently investigating the cause of the fire, he said.

The Oklahoma City fire department was on the scene in challenging conditions, working to get water to douse the flames. It’s currently 8 degrees in the area, and the high temperature for today is only 13 degrees. Winds are blowing at 10-15 miles per hour with gusts up to 25 mph.

Those winds could hinder fire crews but are also dropping the wind chill into the single digits below zero. Wind chills could get to -11 or -12 around midnight.

New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani encouraged people to stay indoors and watch “horrible reality TV” as heavy snow continues to blanket the city.

“We are frankly seeing too many New Yorkers still out on the roads. That’s actually impeding the ability for sanitation to meet this moment,” Mamdani said told CNN, standing near the frozen Harlem Meer in Central Park.

Snow is falling steadily, covering streets, sidewalks and cars in powdery frost. It is also bitterly cold and windy, making conditions increasingly dangerous if there is prolonged exposure.

“This is still going to be the coldest period that New Yorkers have seen for the last 8 years,” Mamdani said.

There are thousands of sanitation workers out on city streets and plows have started to clear roadways. The city has also opened 10 warming centers across the five boroughs for anyone in need of shelter and heated space.

Mamdani said the city’s sanitation workforce has been increased from 2,000 workers to 2,500 working 12-hour shifts.

“These are those people who’ll be doing the work in the moment and the ones who’ll be cleaning up after the fact,” Mamdani said. “Stay home, find some horrible reality TV – today’s the day.”

The massive winter storm has covered more than 1,800 miles of the US from the Rockies to the East Coast in snow and ice since Friday.

[See more photos from the storm.](https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/24/weather/gallery/winter-storm)
